bibl.title: [Letter] Nov. 12, 1919, [Gatlinburg, Tennessee to] family
bibl.note: Autumn coloring everywhere - School subjects - Plans for Thanksgiving program

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

p.del: Dearest Jane - Your nice letter came this Wednesday just as you predicted after I had expected it Monday & then was sure it would come Tuesday - However Monday brought a great long one from Mabel Abbot Cousin Viva & Tues. one from Brennie ditto in length so you see I fared well anyway although your fair handwriting is more welcome & pleasing to the eye than any other! It's 9:30 this eve. & everyone has been in bed for over an hour but myself - I do not want to get the sleep habit though it's sort of a temptation when all the others leave so early - but the newspapers - Literary Digest & such have much news in them & try to look them over even if only hastily.

The youngsters must be too cute & dear for words & would give anything to see them. Can picture you & Miss Pancos in front of the heater peacefully passing away the evenings - am glad she is quick for you have been in a storm center for so long! Mabel's letter was very very nice and interesting & am glad she feels that my letters are for her too

and is so nice as to write me. I try & write pa about twice a week too so you see between the two of you there isn't much left for others - Sunday I dashed off letters to Mr. Snell - Miss Hobroyd - Uncle Art & Charlotte am pleased to say -

As going into business with Mr. St. what sort does he mean? Am not keen for Reedley or any part of the intenar for it's insufficiently am sure - part of the year - are no doubt all right but know first before anything Californians It will friends Don't thing hand work in for that mostly you

make up your mind to that. Why can't he find something else to do in Tacoma. I should think Arthur might be of assistance in that respect. You are quite right when you speak of an upheaval in the midst of the family! But things will eventually work out as we'll know which way to turn.

div1.p: Let me move on now for a minute about the wonderful coloring. Monday was very windy (a regular mt. wind people call it) & which seemed to turn the trees druing the day so that at noon it was really starting to see the change. All had been touched except the evergreens which seem to grow in long fingerlike clusters down the ridges in quite regular stripes like - their dark green contrasts wonderfully with the solid golden color of all the other trees occasionally brightened by a maple - gum tree - sumach or sourwood - a solid mass of falame color from top to bottom & then the copper colored oaks tone that down. Well it's just about the most wonderful thing I've seen here - these golden - green - & red hills in every direction!

Emily Aunt Lizzie & I sat out on the porch steps after lunch today admiring it while waiting for Mr. Creswell to bring up the mail - Evelyn & Miss Langmaid went to Sevierville Sunday afternoon & will be back tomorrow - at least Evelyn phoned tonight to that effect. B.Y. is rather lonesome without her playing & singing as Emily isn't much at the piano - but better than I am anyway. Mr. C. got back from his week-end in time to take charge though Abbie didn't make it until last the next morning. We got through about 7:30 & then Tom McCarter & Mr. C. brought the
lamps over & chatted awhile - Tom is the most amusing & original youngster you can imagine but thoroughly good & dependable. He has been out nearly all month plowing getting in corn etc. & has been learning his part in as Miles Standish while doing the former!

There was a boy shot up in the Sugarlands Sunday noon - by a Mr. Bracken - an elderly man of about sixty - trouble over a still & about which there are conflicting stories - Anyway our Harrison went up after Mr. B. Sunday night - started right after B.Y. on old Dan. It was an awfully windy night way up in the mts. & Harrison looked so excited while telling Mr. C. about fixing the furnace at school etc. for Monday morning. We
can just imagine how Sherlock Holmesy & funny he was. Anyway he got his man & there was a trial by Squire Maples at his house at the foot of our lane to which men for miles around came Monday noon - He was let out on bail until court (circuit every 3 mon.) in February or about then. We were right at the house where was the scene of the shooting on our Smoky trip - stopped to get a horseshoe for Dan.

Well I must on with my tales of my doings such as they are. Monday Abbie stayed with us as the Carr girls did not come to the cottage - Rose being sick & Litha not willing to stay without her I suppose - they get mad about things every so often as do the others. Aunt Lizzie isn't much of a cook you know & wondered what we could have for supper - so I made some
muffins & Jane they were about the best I ever baked - so light - these with our old standby chocolate & some war cake were quite filling - Then great excitement a man come up in a wagon with our dishes a big barrell so after the repast was over down we went with hatchet & lamp & the three of us managed to get the top off & the dishes out of the excelsior - Such a relief as it is to have cups - saucers - bowls etc sufficient for the food & partakers thereof! They are a very pretty pattern neat & chatste! Something like Bavarian dishes - pink roses with a tiny blue flower and a little gold band.

We have sugar bowl - cream pitcher - three sizes of plates - sauce dishes - oatmeal & soup dishes - vegetable dishes & platters besides the cups & saucers - Some of the dinner plates were broken - also vegetable dishes & two platters but we are content with the rest. We washed up enough for breakfast & I arranged the table even to the bread & butter plates. Abbie had brought some little pink chrysanthemums from home so our table looked very pretty. Did I tell you that Evelyn had a large window box in the dining room? in front of the wind It is about a foot wide & three long - wandering Jew - colis - begonia & geraniums make it very pretty.

I stayed till late at school reading about Daniel Boone for my geography class (we have been studying Tenn.) & looking up information about the Constitution for my U.S. class Incidentally I'm learning quite a little myself. We finished the history having be-
gun with the close of the Civil War - The Spanish-American War had been almost entirely erased from my mind & so feel that I'm quite a little more intelligent in regard to my country than before.

Yesterday we didn't close school but had our assembly from 2 till about 2:20 & then dismissed - Liberty Day - you know - It's my week to have assembly but don't mind it any more - We had the flag salute - Star Spangled etc Columbia the gem etc America the beautiful - Mr. C. told about the doings in Liverpool where he was at the time & so ended that part. Then I drilled on my play for a long time & had much fun with them. They are
awfully nice about it & quite interested for them! You know I have Priscilla's part divided between Rose Carr & Cora McCarter thus taking in the four in the 9th grade. Cora has the two spinning scenes as she can spin & we are using our "stage properties" now which makes it more interesting. Have planned to work in the whole class into the last scene closing with a Thanksgiving song. Maybe I've told you all this before - for as you are situated in regard to me & pa so am I towards you both. (No your items in today's letter had not been written me before & was much interested to know of your manifold activities in the bazaar as member of
Aurora P.E.U. & D.A.R. - also was glad to look over year books of first & latter.) After this rehearsing I did a little studying & then went with Emily for a stroll up the river into all the gorgeousness. After supper for which we had some of Aunt Lizzie's good tomato soup we sat around the fireplace & read & talked. Mr. C. came over and joined us - He is alone at the bungalow with Mrs. Proffit & imagine he gets rather lonesome.

Oh yes - he & Tom - Rose & I have been slated for a quartette for the B.Y. Sunday eve! So that's my next feat - unless the boys don't get over their colds before then. What we shall sing is as yet unknown. A hymn no doubt. Rose & I will sing soprano - the other two can sing whatever they wish! Today was a repetition largely of yesterday - more rehearsing after school - Then Emily & I went to the store - Charlie's - for candy - (Is there a sugar famine home as here - ?) He produced a box of chocolates perfectly grand fresh ones - & as he we have not bought any candy since being here we purchased it between us & have had a gay time eating them.

p.del: Well it's getting so late I hate to look at the clock - and must wend my way to bed - Weather is rather warm & damp again so wear my gingham with green slip on & white shoes! Oh yes - this is Brennie's news & a secret - she is engaged! Someone I never heard of & know nothing about - widower named Fred Marsh & Herbert's Sunday School teacher - perfect & she is so happy! Isn't that nice? She is such a dear -
Goodnight dearest Jane with so much love - Ruth
